text: Which root of the permanent maxillary first molar is most commonly associated with having two canals (MB1 and MB2)?
explanation: The maxillary first molar typically has three roots: mesiobuccal, distobuccal, and palatal. While the distobuccal and palatal roots usually contain a single canal, the mesiobuccal root often contains two canals, MB1 and MB2. MB2 is usually located palatal and slightly mesial to MB1 within the pulp chamber floor. Locating and treating both canals is critical for endodontic success because missing MB2 is a common cause of treatment failure. Recognizing this anatomic variation is a classic high-yield fact in dental anatomy and clinical endodontics.

text: Which anterior tooth is most likely to contain two root canals within a single root?
explanation:
Among anterior teeth, the mandibular incisors—especially the mandibular lateral incisor—are most prone to having two canals in one root. The usual pattern is buccal and lingual canals (often Vertucci Type II) that may join before the apex or persist separately. Clinically the lingual canal is easily missed without careful troughing, magnification, and angled radiographs. Maxillary incisors and canines are overwhelmingly single canal; the mandibular canine is remembered more for a possible bifurcated root than canal multiplicity.
Typical Canal Counts — Quick Scan
Tooth# Canals / Prevalence
Mandibular central incisor1C ≈ 70% · 2C ≈ 30%
Mandibular lateral incisor1C ≈ 56% · 2C ≈ 44%
High‑yield review: mandibular lateral incisor—DL incisal twist; root with mesial and distal concavities; possible two canals (B/L); occludes with maxillary central and lateral; cingulum slightly distal and indistinct; incisal edge lingual to long axis from proximal.

text: Which permanent incisor is characterized by a distolingual twist of the incisal edge from the incisal view?
explanation: The mandibular lateral incisor is slightly larger and less symmetrical than the mandibular central and displays a distolingual twist of the incisal edge that follows the arch curvature as teeth transition posteriorly. This trait is a classic differentiator from the straighter, highly symmetrical mandibular central. High‑yield review: mandibular lateral—MMR > DMR; cingulum slightly distal; incisal edge lingual to long axis; root has mesial (deeper) and distal concavities; occludes with maxillary central and lateral incisors.

text: Which anterior tooth may present with a bifurcated root (buccal and lingual)?
explanation: The mandibular canine is the only anterior tooth that may show a bifurcated root with separate buccal and lingual branches. Most mandibular canines are single‑rooted with one canal, but variations include two canals that may remain separate. It also has the longest crown and is the second‑longest tooth overall after the maxillary canine; the root is oval and flattened M‑D with prominent proximal concavities that influence access and extraction mechanics. High‑yield review: mesial cusp ridge < distal; cusp tip slightly lingual to long axis; facial ridge present but less pronounced than maxillary canine; occludes with maxillary lateral incisor and first premolar.

text: Which permanent tooth has a distal marginal ridge that is more prominent than the mesial marginal ridge?
explanation: The mandibular first premolar is unique for DMR > MMR. It features a dominant functional buccal cusp, a small often nonfunctional lingual cusp, a mesiolingual developmental groove that frequently crosses the MMR, and a lingually inclined occlusal plane. These traits influence prep design, occlusal contacts, and caries risk patterns. High‑yield review: occlusal diamond shape; prominent transverse ridge splitting mesial and distal fossae; MMR < DMR; root broader B‑L; occludes with maxillary canine and first premolar.

text: Which tooth is most commonly associated with a C-shaped root canal system?
explanation: A C‑shaped canal is produced by root fusion with fins and isthmuses that yield a continuous C in cross‑section, most classically in the mandibular second molar. Debridement and obturation are challenging due to webs and recesses; use magnification, activated irrigation, and thermoplasticized obturation. High‑yield review: mandibular second molar—rectangular occlusal table; +‑like groove pattern on second molar vs twisted pattern on first; roots closer together and often distally inclined; common site for cervical enamel projections.

text: Which tooth may display a C-shaped developmental groove on its crown?
explanation:
The mandibular second premolar can form in three occlusal patterns, and the three‑cusp Y‑type commonly shows a C‑shaped developmental groove on the lingual between the mesiolingual and distolingual cusps curving toward the central pit. It is the only premolar with five lobes (three buccal and two lingual).
Mandibular 2nd Premolar — Occlusal Configurations
PatternCuspsKey features
Y-type (most common)3 (B, ML, DL)ML > DL; central pit; may show C-shaped groove lingually
H-type2 (B, L)Short central groove; “H” appearance
U-type2 (B, L)Crescent-shaped central groove; “U” appearance
High‑yield review: Y‑type—3 cusps (B, ML, DL), ML > DL, central pit; H‑type—2 cusps with short central groove; U‑type—2 cusps with crescent central groove; lingual HOC often in occlusal third; root longer than mandibular first premolar; apex near mental foramen.

text: Which premolar most commonly has two roots?
explanation:
The maxillary first premolar frequently has two roots (buccal and palatal) and two canals. Classic identifiers include a mesial marginal ridge groove, a deep mesial root concavity, and the unique mesial cusp ridge longer than distal. These features complicate scaling, impressioning, and endodontic access.
Maxillary 1st Premolar — Canal Counts
# canals123
Prevalence≈ 9%≈ 85%≈ 6%
High‑yield review: occlusal hexagon; long central groove with fewer supplemental grooves; buccal cusp > palatal; proximal trapezoid; often no central pit (separate mesial and distal pits).

text: Which posterior tooth has its lingual height of contour in the occlusal third rather than the middle third?
explanation: For posterior teeth, the buccal height of contour is consistently in the cervical third and the lingual height of contour is normally in the middle third. The mandibular second premolar is the exception: prominent lingual cusp development (especially in three‑cusp form) shifts the lingual height of contour into the occlusal third. High‑yield review: only premolar with five lobes; Y/H/U patterns; lingual cusp(s) relatively tall; square occlusal outline in 2‑cusp forms.

text: Which tooth has the most prominent labial ridge?
explanation: The labial ridge occurs only on canines and is most prominent on the maxillary canine due to robust facial lobe development. Compare ridges for rapid ID: buccal (cusp) ridge—only on premolars, most pronounced on the maxillary first premolar; cervical ridge—on all primary teeth and permanent molars across the cervical third of the buccal surface; marginal ridge—on all teeth, forming mesial/distal borders of posterior occlusal surfaces and anterior lingual surfaces; oblique ridge—on maxillary molars from ML to DB cusps; triangular ridges—on all posterior cusps (ML cusp of maxillary molars has two triangular ridges); transverse ridge—when opposing triangular ridges meet (common on maxillary premolars and mandibular molars).

text: Which permanent teeth are least likely to be lost due to caries?
explanation: Mandibular incisors are least likely to be lost to caries because of small, smooth crowns, continuous cleansing by tongue and saliva, and minimal pits/fissures. They are more often threatened by periodontal disease or crowding than decay. In contrast, maxillary first molars are caries‑prone due to early eruption and complex occlusal anatomy. High‑yield review: mandibular incisors—smallest (central), most symmetrical (central), incisal edge lingual to long axis, cingulum indistinct, mesial CEJ curvature greatest among mandibular teeth.

text: Which nerves typically innervate the roots of the maxillary first molar?
option1: All roots by the posterior superior alveolar nerve
option2: Distobuccal and palatal roots by PSA; mesiobuccal root by MSA
option3: Mesiobuccal and distobuccal roots by ASA; palatal root by nasopalatine nerve
option4: Palatal root by greater palatine; buccal roots by PSA
explanation: The maxillary first molar commonly shows dual innervation: the distobuccal and palatal roots are supplied by the posterior superior alveolar nerve, while the mesiobuccal root is often supplied by the middle superior alveolar nerve. Because the MSA can be absent with ASA/PSA overlap, a PSA infiltration alone may not numb the MB root; consider supplemental infiltration over the MB root or an MSA block when present. High‑yield review: three roots—palatal (longest), MB, DB (shortest); prominent oblique ridge; DL cusp smallest; possible cusp of Carabelli on ML cusp.

text: The maxillary first molar usually has how many canals?
explanation:
The classic expectation is three canals (one per root), but four canals are also common because the MB root frequently contains two canals (MB1 and MB2). Always explore the MB root carefully with troughing and magnification to locate MB2.
Maxillary 1st Molar — Canal Counts
Overall canals34 (MB2)
Prevalence≈ 60–70%≈ 30–40%
High‑yield review: 3 roots—palatal longest, DB shortest; pronounced oblique ridge; primary cusp triangle (ML, MB, DB); DL cusp smallest; furcation distances: mesial < buccal < distal.

text: The mandibular first molar most commonly presents with how many canals?
explanation:
The typical pattern is two canals in the mesial root (MB and ML) and one in the distal root for a total of three canals. A second distal canal may be present, giving four canals; inspect the distal root carefully when anatomy suggests it.
Mandibular 1st Molar — Canal Counts
Overall canals34
Prevalence≈ 60–70%≈ 30–40%
High‑yield review: five cusps (MB largest, distal smallest, ML tallest); pentagonal occlusal outline; +‑like occlusal pattern with twisted central groove; root trunk shorter than second molar; mesial root wider B‑L and usually longer.

text: Between mandibular premolars, which tooth is more likely to have two canals?
explanation:
The mandibular first premolar shows two canals far more often than the mandibular second premolar, which is usually single canal. Persistent symptoms after treatment of a mandibular first premolar should trigger a search for a second canal.
Mandibular Premolars — Canal Counts
Tooth1C2C3C
Mand 1st premolar≈ 73%≈ 25%≈ 1%
Mand 2nd premolar≈ 97.5%≈ 2.5%—
High‑yield review: mandibular first premolar—dominant buccal cusp, small nonfunctional lingual cusp, strong transverse ridge, frequent mesiolingual groove, DMR > MMR; mandibular second premolar—only premolar with five lobes, Y/H/U occlusal patterns, lingual HOC often occlusal third.
